metadata.title: Jamison v. Sunrise Ladder Co., Inc.

matter.summary: Wrongful death action arising from ladder defect. Bruce Jamison died after falling from a defective Sunrise ladder on March 10, 2024. Critical evidence (rung locks) was destroyed by Advanced Testing, LLC, a third-party laboratory hired by defendant Sunrise, before plaintiff could examine it. Plaintiff seeks to determine remedies for spoliation of evidence.
parties: Valerie Jamison (Plaintiff - Widow of Bruce Jamison)
Advanced Testing, LLC (Third Party - Testing laboratory that destroyed evidence)

documents.title: Deposition of Bruce Jamison (Decedent)
documents.summary: Decedent's testimony taken before his death. He stated on March 10, 2024, he was climbing his Sunrise ladder when one of the spring-loaded rung locks gave way, causing the ladder to collapse. He specifically stated: 'I saw that the left rung lock wasn't holding right. There was something wrong with the spring or something.'
facts: Ladder purchased from Sunrise retailer in 2023
Decedent noticed left rung lock malfunctioned
Ladder collapsed causing fall and injuries
Decedent observed mechanical failure in rung lock mechanism

documents.title: Sunrise Letter to Advanced Testing
documents.summary: Letter from Sunrise General Counsel Robert Hayward instructing Advanced Testing to conduct 'non-destructive testing only' on the ladder and preserve all components.
facts: Sunrise explicitly requested non-destructive testing
Letter instructed preservation of all components
Sunrise was aware of potential litigation

documents.title: Advanced Testing Internal Memorandum
documents.summary: Internal memo from Advanced Testing director Mark Paulson stating the rung locks were corroded and required 'stress testing to failure.' Memo notes: 'Testing will destroy the components but will provide definitive data on manufacturing defect.'
facts: Advanced Testing knew testing would destroy components
Director authorized destructive testing despite Sunrise instructions
Components were destroyed during stress testing
Testing was allegedly to determine manufacturing defect

documents.title: Letter from Plaintiff's Counsel to Sunrise
documents.summary: Demand from Jamison's counsel requesting preservation of all physical evidence, specifically the ladder and all components including rung locks.
facts: Plaintiff formally demanded evidence preservation
Request specifically mentioned rung locks
Sent before Advanced Testing completed destructive testing

documents.title: Response from Sunrise Counsel
documents.summary: Sunrise counsel responded stating the ladder was with Advanced Testing for examination and all evidence was being preserved.
facts: Sunrise represented evidence was being preserved
Failed to disclose ongoing destructive testing
Misrepresentation to opposing counsel

documents.title: Advanced Testing Report
documents.summary: Final report from Advanced Testing. States rung locks were destroyed during 'comprehensive stress analysis.' Report concludes components showed 'significant corrosion' but cannot determine if defect was manufacturing-related because components no longer exist.
facts: Rung locks completely destroyed during testing
Cannot make definitive determination on manufacturing defect
Evidence that could prove or disprove plaintiff's theory is gone
Testing methodology was destructive contrary to instructions

documents.title: Plaintiff's Expert Declaration
documents.summary: Declaration from plaintiff's metallurgical expert stating that without examining the actual rung locks, she cannot definitively opine on whether the failure was due to manufacturing defect, design defect, or user error.
facts: Expert cannot form definitive opinion without physical evidence
Plaintiff prejudiced by loss of evidence
Other ladder components insufficient to prove manufacturing defect theory

events.description: Bruce Jamison falls from Sunrise ladder due to rung lock failure
Plaintiff files wrongful death complaint against Sunrise
Sunrise sends ladder to Advanced Testing with preservation instructions
Advanced Testing decides to conduct destructive testing
Plaintiff's counsel demands preservation of evidence
Sunrise counsel misrepresents that evidence is being preserved
Advanced Testing destroys rung locks during stress testing
Advanced Testing delivers report; destruction of evidence disclosed
Bruce Jamison dies from injuries sustained in fall

issues.issue: Spoliation Sanctions Against Sunrise: Can Mrs. Jamison obtain sanctions, including possible default judgment, against Sunrise for the destruction of evidence by Advanced Testing?
facts: Sunrise had duty to preserve evidence once litigation was anticipated
Sunrise sent ladder to third party for testing
Third party destroyed critical evidence
Plaintiff demands adverse inference or default judgment
Apply Brown v. Waldrop factors for sanctions analysis

issues.issue: Independent Tort Action Against Advanced Testing: Can Mrs. Jamison bring an independent tort action against Advanced Testing for spoliation of evidence?
facts: Advanced Testing is not a party to the underlying lawsuit
Advanced Testing intentionally destroyed evidence despite contrary instructions
Destruction of evidence prejudices plaintiff's ability to prove case
Advanced Testing knew of pending litigation
Apply Zubul v. Standard Motors elements for independent tort analysis

authorities.cite: Brown v. Waldrop (Columbia Court of Appeal, 2020)
authorities.summary: Sanctions for spoliation appropriate where party fails to preserve evidence after duty to preserve attaches. Duty arises when litigation is reasonably anticipated. Party responsible for destruction by agents acting on their behalf. Sanctions include adverse inference, issue preclusion, or dismissal. Court considers prejudice to opposing party.

authorities.cite: Zubul v. Standard Motors (Columbia Supreme Court, 2018)
authorities.summary: Independent tort action for intentional spoliation lies against third party who destroys evidence with knowledge of pending litigation. Elements: (1) existence of potential lawsuit; (2) defendant's knowledge of potential lawsuit; (3) intentional destruction of evidence; (4) causal connection between destruction and inability to prove underlying claim; (5) damages. Destruction must be intentional not negligent.

goals.remedy: Advise client on remedies available for spoliation of evidence and determine whether to pursue sanctions against Sunrise or separate action against Advanced Testing
goals.ideal: Obtain both sanctions against Sunrise and independent tort recovery against Advanced Testing
goals.minimum: Secure adverse inference instruction or other meaningful sanction against Sunrise

structure: Introduction acknowledging client's case and purpose of letter
Analysis of Question 1: Sanctions against Sunrise for spoliation
Analysis of Question 2: Independent tort action against Advanced Testing
requirements: Apply Brown v. Waldrop factors to sanctions analysis
Apply Zubul v. Standard Motors elements to independent tort analysis
Use heading for each major issue
Do not include statement of facts

strengths: Clear evidence of litigation being anticipated when destruction occurred
Plaintiff clearly prejudiced by loss of evidence
Both cases in Library support plaintiff's position
weaknesses: Sunrise did instruct preservation - may argue lack of intent
Advanced Testing may claim good faith belief testing was necessary
Causation between destruction and inability to prove claim may be disputed
